key_points: The planning for the Capitol assault on January 6 was extensively discussed in far-right forums, including plans to handcuff lawmakers.
Researchers and groups like SITE Intelligence Group warned of the planned assault weeks before it happened.
The Capitol Police were criticized for being unprepared despite the explicit warnings.
Twitter suspended President Trumpâ€™s account to prevent a potential 'secondary attack' on U.S. Capitol and state government facilities.
Online calls for protests leading up to President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration include plans for a 'Million Militia March' on January 20.
There has been violent talk and plans shared on both mainstream and niche conservative online platforms.
Officials were warned about the potential violence, including detailed plans to smuggle guns and attack political figures.
Some activists who normally avoid cooperating with law enforcement reported their concerns to the FBI.
Federal, state, and local law enforcement have been enhancing their intelligence capabilities since the September 11 attacks.
The lax preparation and response to the Capitol siege raised questions about law enforcement's readiness and willingness to address such threats.
spokespersons: Rita Katz (Executive Director of SITE Intelligence Group)
Brian Harrell (Former Trump administration Department of Homeland Security assistant secretary for infrastructure protection, now Chief Security Officer for Avangrid)
Marc Ginsberg (President of the Coalition for a Safer Web)
